sectionTitle: Alternative Definitions of Operating Cash Flow

columns.text: In this problem, we need to identify the different approaches of defining the operating cash flow of a company or a project.
**a.** The operating cash flow is defined as the amount of cash being generated by the project or company. There are two approaches when defining the operating cash flow.

The **top-down** approach uses the sales as basis while subtracting the operating costs from this income. Moreover, in this approach, the depreciation is not included in the calculation since it is a noncash item.
The **bottom-up** approach is the opposite since it starts with the net income and the expenses are added back. Aside from that, noncash items are also included in the computation.
**10.5a** In this part of the question, we are asked to define the top-down and bottom up operating cash flows.

**Top-down** is an accounting term that refers to the starting point of an income statement. The top-down approach begins with the company's revenues and then deducts expenses to arrive at the company's operating cash flow.

**Bottom-up** is an accounting term that refers to the ending point of an income statement. The bottom-up approach begins with the company's operating cash flows and then adds back in any profits or losses from investments. Both top-down and bottom-up approaches can be used in financial statements, but the bottom-up approach is more common because it is simpler to understand.
In both cases, operating cash flow is a measure of a company's ability to generate money from its operations.
**10.5b** In this part of the question, we are asked to define the depreciation tax shield.

The **depreciation tax shield** is the tax savings generated by the depreciation of a fixed asset. The depreciation tax shield is calculated by multiplying the depreciation deduction by the tax rate. In equation form,

$$\text{ Depreciation Tax Shield = Depreciation Expense } \times \text{ Tax Rate}$$

For example, if a company owns a fixed asset that has a $10,000 depreciation deduction and the tax rate is 25%. Hence we have:
$$
\begin{aligned}
\text{ Depreciation Tax Shield} & = \$10,000 \times 0.25\\[15pt]
& = \$2,500
\end{aligned}
$$
*The depreciation tax shield, or the savings of the company in taxes is $2,500.*

This amount is saved even if the company does not pay any taxes on its income. There are a few limitations on the depreciation tax shield, but it is one of the most important tax breaks available to businesses.
